  <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">

  <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Exhibit Index is on Page 63<br>
&nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid">
  <u>PART I</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><u>
  Item 1.</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  <u>Description of Business</u></p>
  <p style="margin-left: .5in"><font size="3">General</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyText" style="line-height: normal; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company is a processor, manufacturer and distributor of a broad array of
  high value-added, high margin products and services.&nbsp; The Company utilizes any
  one or a combination of several different processes at each of its operating
  facilities to add margin and value to raw materials acquired from primary
  steel and other metal producers.&nbsp; Underlying each of these processes and
  services is a common set of core competencies in manufacturing, processing and
  distribution.&nbsp; These core competencies are the foundation upon which all the
  Company's operations and products and services are based.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company is organized into three reportable
  segments - Processed Metal Products, Building Products and Thermal
  Processing.&nbsp; The Processed Metal Products segment produces a wide variety of
  cold-rolled strip steel products, coated sheet steel products, strapping
  products and powdered metal products in 17 facilities in 8 states.&nbsp; The
  Company's processed cold-rolled strip steel products comprise a part of the
  cold-rolled sheet steel market that is defined by more precise widths,
  improved surface conditions, more diverse chemistry and tighter gauge
  tolerances than are supplied by primary manufacturers of flat-rolled steel
  products.&nbsp; The Company's cold-rolled strip steel products are sold primarily
  to manufacturers in the automotive, automotive supply, power and hand tool and
  hardware industries, as well as to other customers who demand critical
  specifications in their raw material needs.&nbsp; The Company's coated steel
  products, which include galvanized, galvalume and pre-painted sheet products,
  are sold primarily to the commercial and residential metal building industry
  for roofing and siding applications.&nbsp; The Company's heavy duty steel strapping
  products are used to close and reinforce packages such as cartons and crates
  for shipping.&nbsp; The Company's non-ferrous powdered metal products are sold to
  manufacturers in the automotive, aerospace, electronics and consumer products
  industries.&nbsp; The Company also operates two material management facilities that
  link primary steel producers to end-user manufacturers.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Building Products segment, comprised of 42
  facilities in 21 states and Canada, primarily includes the manufacturing and
  distribution of a wide variety of building and construction products.&nbsp; Many of
  the Company's building products meet and exceed increasingly stringent
  building codes and insurance company requirements governing both residential
  and commercial construction.&nbsp; Most of our businesses operate in niche markets
  and have high market share.&nbsp; Most of our manufactured products have national
  presence and are innovative in their markets.&nbsp; This segment's products are
  sold to major retail home centers, lumber and building material wholesalers,
  buying groups, discount stores, distributors, and general contractors engaged
  in residential, industrial and commercial construction.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Thermal Processing segment operates 16
  facilities in 10 states and Canada
  and provides a wide array of processes which refine the metallurgical
  properties of customer-owned metal products for a variety of consumer and
  industrial applications where critical performance characteristics are
  required.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Note 16 of the Company's consolidated
  financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides information related to
  the Company's business segments in accordance with accounting principles
  generally accepted in the United States of America.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Recent Developments </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  In April 2003, the Company acquired
  Construction Metals, Inc. (Construction Metals).&nbsp; As part of the purchase
  agreement between the Company and the former owners of Construction Metals,
  the Company may be required to pay additional consideration if certain net
  sales levels as defined in the purchase agreement are achieved during the
  period from acquisition up to March 31, 2006. During the second quarter of
  2004 a payment of $345,000 was made pursuant to the additional consideration,
  and was recorded as additional goodwill.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  On January 6, 2004, the Company acquired
  Renown Specialties Company Ltd. (Renown), which operates a manufacturing
  facility in Thornhill,
  Ontario.&nbsp; Renown is a designer, manufacturer
  and distributor of construction hardware products in Canada.&nbsp; Note 2 of the
  Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides
  additional information regarding the Company's acquisition of Renown.
  </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">In
  connection with the Company's 2003 common stock offering, the Company granted
  the underwriters an option to purchase additional shares of common stock to
  cover over-allotments.&nbsp; In January 2004, the underwriters exercised a portion
  of this option and purchased an additional 321,938 shares of the Company's
  common stock at a price of $16.50 per share.&nbsp; Net proceeds to the Company
  associated with the purchase of these additional shares aggregated
  approximately $5 million. Note 11 of the
  Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides
  additional information regarding the Company's common stock offering.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  On June 1, 2004, the Company acquired SCM
  Metal Products, Inc. (SCM), which operates a manufacturing facility in
  Research Triangle Park, North Carolina.&nbsp; SCM manufactures, markets and
  distributes non&#8722;ferrous metal powder products to customers in a number of
  different industries, including the automotive, aerospace, electronics and
  consumer products industries. Note 2 of the Company's consolidated financial
  statements included in Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding
  the Company's acquisition of SCM. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  On August 13, 2004 the Company acquired
  Portals Plus Incorporated and its affiliated companies, Roofing Products &amp;
  Systems Corporation and J.L.R. Services, Inc. (Portals Plus), which operates
  two manufacturing facilities in Chicago,
  Illinois.&nbsp; Portals Plus manufactures a
  diverse line of roofing products. Note 2 of the Company's consolidated
  financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides additional information
  regarding the Company's acquisition of Portals.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  On October 4, 2004, the Board of Directors
  authorized a three&#8722;for&#8722;two common stock split in the form of a stock dividend.
  The stock dividend was distributed on October 29, 2004 to stockholders of
  record on October 15, 2004. All share and per share data in these financial
  statements give effect to the stock split, applied retroactively to all
  periods. Note 12 of the Company's consolidated financial statements included
  in Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding the Company's stock
  split.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  On October 26, 2004, at a Special Meeting of
  Stockholders, the Company's stockholders authorized an amendment to the
  Company's Certificate of Incorporation to change the name of the Company from
  Gibraltar Steel Corporation to Gibraltar Industries, Inc. The name change
  became effective on October 27, 2004.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in; margin-right: 9.0pt; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  On January 27, 2005, the Company sold the
  assets of its Milcor subsidiary for approximately $42 million.&nbsp; We do not
  expect to incur a material gain or loss from this transaction.</p>
  <p style="margin-left: .5in"><font size="3">Industry
  Overview</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Steel and metal processors occupy a market
  niche that exists between the primary steel and metal producers and end-users
  and others.&nbsp; Primary steel and metal producers typically focus on the sale of
  standard size and tolerance steel and other metals to large volume purchasers,
  including steel and metal processors.&nbsp; At the same time, end-users require
  steel with closer tolerances and with shorter lead times than the primary
  steel and metal producers can provide efficiently.&nbsp; Steel processors, through
  the application of various higher value-added processes such as cold-rolling
  and specialized heat-treating methods, process steel of a precise grade,
  temper, tolerance and finish.&nbsp; End product manufacturers incorporate the
  processed steel into finished goods.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Products and Services<br>
  <i>
  <br>
  Processed Metal Products Segment<br>
  Cold-Rolled Strip Steel</i>.&nbsp;
  The Company's cold-rolled strip steel is used in applications which demand
  more precise widths, improved surface conditions and tighter gauge tolerances
  than are supplied by primary producers of flat-rolled steel products.&nbsp;
  Consistent with its strategy of focusing on high value-added products and
  services, the Company produces a broad range of fully processed cold-rolled
  strip steel products.&nbsp; The Company buys wide, open tolerance sheet steel in
  coils from primary producers and processes it to specific customer orders by
  performing such computer-aided processes as cold reduction, annealing, edge
  rolling and slitting.&nbsp; Cold reduction is the rolling of steel to a specified
  thickness, tolerance and finish.&nbsp; Annealing is a thermal process which changes
  hardness and certain metallurgical characteristics of steel.&nbsp; Edge rolling
  involves conditioning edges of processed steel into square, full round or
  partially round shapes.&nbsp; Slitting is the cutting of steel to specified
  widths.&nbsp; Depending on customer specifications, one or more of these processes
  are utilized to produce steel strip of a precise grade, temper, tolerance and
  finish.&nbsp; Customers for the Company's strip steel products include
  manufacturers in the automotive, automotive supply, power and hand tool,
  hardware and other industries.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company operates nine rolling mills at its
  facilities in Cleveland, Ohio and Buffalo,
  New York, all of which are QS-9000
  registered.&nbsp; Equipment at these facilities includes a computerized,
  three-stand, four-high tandem mill and eight single-stand, two- and four-high
  mills.&nbsp; The Company has the capability to process coils up to a maximum of 72
  inch outside diameter and roll widths of up to 50 inches.&nbsp; Its rolling mills
  include automatic gauge control systems with hydraulic screw downs allowing
  for microsecond adjustments during processing.&nbsp; The Company's computerized
  mills enable it to satisfy an industry demand for a wide range of steel from
  heavier gauge and special alloy steels to low carbon and light gauge steels,
  in each case having a high-quality finish and precision gauge tolerance.&nbsp; This
  equipment can process flat-rolled steel to specific customer requirements for
  thickness tolerances as close as .00025 inches.&nbsp; The Company also operates a
  56-inch reversing mill which it believes is one of the widest of its type in
  the specialty strip steel industry.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's rolling facilities are further complemented by 17
  high-convection annealing furnaces, which allow for shorter annealing times
  than conventional annealers.&nbsp; Fourteen of the Company's furnaces and bases
  employ state-of-the-art technology, incorporating the use of a hydrogen
  atmosphere for the production of cleaner and more uniform steel.&nbsp; As a result
  of the Company's annealing capabilities, it is able to produce cold-rolled
  strip steel with improved consistency in terms of thickness, hardness,
  molecular grain structure and surface.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company can produce certain strip steel
  products on oscillated coils, which wind strip steel similar to the way
  fishing line is wound on a reel.&nbsp; Oscillating the strip steel enables the
  Company to put at least six times greater volume of finished product on a coil
  than standard ribbon winding, allowing customers to achieve longer production
  runs by reducing the number of equipment shut-downs to change coils.&nbsp;
  Customers are thus able to increase productivity, reduce downtime, improve
  yield and lengthen die life.&nbsp; These benefits to customers allow the Company to
  achieve higher margins on oscillate products.&nbsp; To the Company's knowledge,
  only a few other steel producers are able to produce oscillated coils, and the
  Company is not aware of any competitor that can produce 12,000 pound oscillate
  coils, the maximum size the Company produces.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Cold-Rolled Strip Steel Joint Venture.</i>&nbsp;
  The Company has a 50% interest in a joint venture that has one facility in
  Pennsylvania where it manufacturers and distributes cold-rolled strip steel
  products.&nbsp; Note 6 of the Company's consolidated financial statements included
  in Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding the Company's 50%
  interest in the joint venture.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Steel Strapping Products.</i>&nbsp;
  Steel strapping is a binding and packaging material used to close and
  reinforce shipping units such as bales, boxes, cartons, coils, crates and
  skids.&nbsp; The Company is one of only four domestic manufacturers of high-tensile
  steel strapping, which is subject to strength requirements imposed by the
  American Society for Testing Materials for packaging of different products for
  common carrier transport.&nbsp; This high-tensile steel strapping is essential to
  producers of large, heavy products such as steel, paper and lumber where
  reliability of the packaging material is critical to the safe transport of the
  product.&nbsp; The Company's steel strapping facility is QS-9000 and ISO-14001
  registered and is located in Buffalo,
  New York.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Metal Powder Products.</i>&nbsp;
  The Company operates a manufacturing facility in Research Triangle Park, North
  Carolina that manufactures, markets and distributes nonferrous metal powder
  products to customers in a number of different industries, including the
  automotive, aerospace, electronics and consumer products industries.
  </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Coated Steel Products.&nbsp; </i>
  The Company's coated steel products are used
  primarily in the building products and construction markets and include
  galvanized and galvalume, pre-painted cold rolled galvanized &amp; galvalume,
  acrylic coated galvanized &amp; galvalume and PVC coatings for spiral pipe.&nbsp;
  Materials are available in an unlimited number of colors and coating
  qualities.&nbsp; The Company's cold-rolled low carbon drawing steels and high
  strength low alloy steels are used primarily in the automotive market and are
  supplied to second and third tier automotive-stamping manufacturers.&nbsp; In
  addition, one of the Company's two locations which produces coated steel
  products is ISO-900l registered.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Materials Management.&nbsp; </i>
  The Company also operates two state-of-the-art
  materials management facilities in New York and Michigan that link primary
  steel producers and end-user manufacturers by integrating the inventory
  purchasing, receiving, inspection, billing, storage and shipping functions and
  producing true just-in-time delivery of materials.&nbsp; The Company's facilities
  receive shipments of steel by rail and truck from primary steel producers,
  which retain ownership of the steel until it is delivered to the end-user
  manufacturer.&nbsp; The Company inspects the steel and stores it in a
  climate-controlled environment on a specialized stacker crane and rack
  system.&nbsp; When an order is placed, the Company can deliver the steel to the
  end-user manufacturer within one hour using trucks that have been custom
  designed for facilitating the loading and unloading process. &nbsp;This enables
  end-user manufacturers to reduce their raw material inventory.&nbsp; These
  facilities are ISO-9001 registered and have certain proprietary data
  processing systems that link the primary steel producer with the end-user
  manufacturer and also link both parties to the facilities.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Steel Pickling Joint Venture.&nbsp; </i>
  The Company has a 31% interest in a joint
  venture that has two steel pickling operations in Ohio.&nbsp; After the hot-rolling
  process, the surface of sheet steel is left with a residue known as scale,
  which must be removed prior to further processing by a cleaning process known
  as pickling.&nbsp; This joint venture pickles steel on a toll basis, receiving fees
  for pickling services without acquiring ownership of the steel.&nbsp; Note 6 of the
  Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides
  additional information regarding the Company's 31% interest in the joint
  venture.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Building Products Segment<br>
  </i>The Building Products segment is the result of
  the acquisition of eleven synergistic businesses over the last eight years
  that are primarily, but not exclusively, manufacturers of metal products used
  in the residential and light commercial building market.&nbsp; As a result, the
  Company operates 42 facilities throughout the United States and in Canada
  giving it a national base of operations to provide customer support, delivery,
  service and quality to a number of regional and nationally based customers, as
  well as providing the Company with manufacturing and distribution
  efficiencies.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company manufactures more than 5,000
  products sold to lumber and building material wholesalers, buying groups,
  discount and major retail home centers, HVAC/roofing distributors and
  residential, industrial and commercial contractors.&nbsp; The Company's product
  offerings include a full line of ventilation products and accessories;
  mailboxes; roof edging, underlayment and flashing; soffit; drywall corner
  bead; structural support products; coated coil stock; metal roofing and
  accessories; steel framing; rain-carrying systems, including gutters and
  accessories; bath cabinets; access doors; roof hatches and smoke vents;
  builders' hardware, shelving and closet rods; grilles and registers;
  diffusers; and fasteners, each of which can be sold separately or as an
  integral part of a package or program sale.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Many of the Company's products are used to integrate the architectural design
  and building process, improve the life expectancy and functionality of a
  structure or its components, including situations of severe weather or seismic
  activity, and facilitate compliance with increasingly stringent building codes
  and insurance company requirements.<br>
  <br>
  The Company's building products are
  manufactured primarily from galvanized, galvalume and painted steel, anodized
  and painted aluminum, copper, brass, zinc and various plastic compounds.&nbsp;
  These additional metal purchases, when added to the Company's existing
  Processed Metal Products segment purchases, enhance the Company's purchasing
  position due to the increased total volume and value added component of these
  purchases.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's production capabilities allow it
  to process the wide range of metals and plastics necessary for manufacturing
  building products.&nbsp; The Company's equipment includes automatic roll forming
  machines, stamping presses, shears, press brakes, paint lines, milling,
  welding, injection molding and numerous automated assembly machines.&nbsp; All
  equipment is maintained through a constant preventative maintenance program,
  including in-house tool and die shops, allowing the Company to meet the
  demanding service requirements of many of its customers.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Building Products segment has operating
  facilities located in Arizona,
  California, Colorado,
  Florida,
  Georgia, Illinois,
  Iowa, Michigan,
  Minnesota, Mississippi,
  Nebraska,
  Nevada,
  New Mexico, New Jersey,
  North Carolina, Ohio,
  Tennessee, Texas,
  Utah, Washington,
  Wisconsin and Ontario,
  Canada.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><i>
  Thermal Processing Segment<br>
  </i>The Company's Thermal Processing segment
  provides a wide range of metallurgical heat-treating processes in which
  customer-owned metal parts are exposed to precise temperatures, atmospheres
  and quenchants and other conditions to improve their mechanical properties,
  durability and wear resistance.&nbsp; These processes include case-hardening,
  neutral-hardening and through-hardening, annealing, normalizing, vacuum
  hardening, carburizing, nitriding and brazing, as well as a host of other
  processes.&nbsp; Thermal processing can harden, soften or otherwise impart desired
  properties to parts made of steel, aluminum, copper, powdered metals and
  various alloys and other metals.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company operates 16 thermal processing
  facilities in Alabama, Georgia,
  Illinois, Indiana,
  Michigan,
  North Carolina, Ohio,
  Pennsylvania, South Carolina,
  Tennessee and Ontario,
  Canada.&nbsp; The Company maintains a
  metallurgical laboratory at each facility with trained metallurgists providing
  a range of testing capabilities to add value to treated parts and enhance
  quality control.&nbsp; Consistent quality control is maintained by application of a
  statistical process control system and QS-9000 or ISO-9001 registration.&nbsp; In
  addition, 3 of the Company's thermal processing facilities are ISO-14001
  registered.&nbsp; The Company also maintains a fleet of trucks and trailers to
  provide rapid turnaround time for its customers.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Due to time and costs associated with transporting materials and customers'
  need for just-in-time delivery of thermal processed products, the commercial
  thermal processing industry has developed as a regional industry concentrated
  in major industrial areas of the country.&nbsp; In addition, the commercial
  thermal processing industry has realized significant growth in recent years as
  many companies involved in the manufacture of metal components outsource their
  thermal processing requirements.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Quality Assurance</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company places great importance on
  providing its customers with high-quality products for use in critical
  applications.&nbsp; The Company carefully selects its raw material vendors and uses
  computerized inspection and analysis to ensure that the materials entering its
  production processes will be able to meet the most critical customer
  specifications.&nbsp; To ensure these specifications are met, the Company uses
  documented procedures utilizing statistical process control systems linked
  directly to processing equipment to monitor all stages of production.&nbsp;
  Physical, chemical and metallographic analyses are performed during the
  production process to verify that mechanical and dimensional properties,
  cleanliness, surface characteristics and chemical content are within
  specification.&nbsp; In addition, all of the Company's facilities that provide
  services or products to the automotive industry, including 13 of the Company's
  thermal processing facilities, are QS-9000 registered.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Suppliers and Raw Materials</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Steel and metal processing companies are
  required to maintain substantial inventories of raw material in order to
  accommodate the short lead times and just-in-time delivery requirements of
  their customers.&nbsp; Accordingly, the Company generally maintains its inventory
  of raw materials at levels that it believes are sufficient to satisfy the
  anticipated needs of its customers based upon historic buying practices and
  market conditions.&nbsp; The primary raw material processed by the Company is
  flat-rolled steel, purchased at regular intervals on an as-needed basis
  primarily from approximately 37 major North American suppliers, as well as a
  limited number of foreign steel suppliers.&nbsp; The Company has no long-term
  commitments with any of its suppliers.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Technical Services</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company employs a staff of engineers,
  metallurgists, and other technical personnel and maintains fully-equipped,
  modern laboratories to support its operations.&nbsp; These laboratories enable the
  Company to verify, analyze and document the physical, chemical, metallurgical
  and mechanical properties of its raw materials and products.&nbsp; In addition, the
  Company's engineering staff also employs a range of CAD/CAM programs to design
  highly specialized and technically precise products.&nbsp; Technical service
  personnel also work in conjunction with the Company's sales force to determine
  the types of products and services required for the particular needs of the
  Company's customers.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Sales and Marketing</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's products and services are sold
  primarily by Company sales personnel and outside sales representatives located
  throughout the United States, Canada and Mexico. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Customers and Distribution</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company has approximately 10,000 customers
  located throughout the United States,
  Canada and Mexico principally in the automotive, automotive supply, building
  and construction, steel, machinery and general manufacturing industries.&nbsp;
  &nbsp;&nbsp;Major customers include automobile manufacturers and suppliers, building
  product distributors, and commercial and residential contractors.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  During 2003 and 2004, one customer of the
  Company (The Home Depot), accounted for 10.7% and 11.1%, respectively, &nbsp;of the
  Company's consolidated net sales.&nbsp; No other customer represented 10% or more
  of the Company's consolidated net sales for 2003 and 2004.&nbsp; &nbsp;No one customer
  of the Company represented 10% or more of the Company's consolidated net sales
  for 2002.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  During 2002, one customer (General Motors) of
  the Company's Processed Metal Products segment accounted for 10.4% &nbsp;of this
  segment's net sales.&nbsp; No one customer of the Company's Processed Metal
  Products segment represented 10% or more of this segment's net sales for 2003
  and 2004.&nbsp; During 2002, 2003 and 2004, one customer (The Home Depot) of the
  Company's Building Products segment accounted for 18.5%, 20.3%, and 21.8% ,
  respectively, of this segment's net sales.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  No one other single customer accounted for
  more than 10% of the Company's Building Products segment net sales during this
  three year period.&nbsp; No one customer of the Company's Thermal Processing
  segment represented 10% or more of this segment's net sales for 2002, 2003 and
  2004.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's Processed Metal Products and
  Building Products segments manufacture products to both customer order and
  inventory.&nbsp; The Thermal Processing segment processes customer owned metal
  parts to various metallurgical thermal processing specifications.&nbsp; Although
  the Company negotiates annual sales orders with the majority of its customers,
  these orders are subject to customer confirmation as to product amounts and
  delivery dates.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Competition</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The metal processing market is highly
  competitive.&nbsp; The Company competes with a small number of other metal
  &nbsp;processors, some of which also focus on fully processed, high value-added
  metal products.&nbsp; The Company competes on the basis of precision and range of
  achievable tolerances, quality, price and the ability to meet delivery
  schedules dictated by customers.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company competes with numerous suppliers
  of building products in its market based on the broad range of products
  offered, quality, price and delivery.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company competes with a small number of
  suppliers of thermal processing services in its market areas on the basis of
  processes offered, quality, price and delivery.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Employees</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  At December 31, 2004,
  the Company employed approximately 3,900 people, of which 622, or
  approximately 16%, are represented by collective bargaining agreements.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Seasonability</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's revenues are generally lower in the first and fourth quarters
  primarily due to customer plant shutdowns in the automotive industry due to
  <font size="3">due to holidays and model
  changeovers, as well as reduced activity in the building and construction industry due to inclement weather.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  &nbsp;Backlog</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Because of the nature of the Company's
  products and the short lead time order cycle, backlog is not a significant
  factor in the Company's business.&nbsp; The Company believes that substantially all
  of its firm orders existing on December 31, 2004 will be shipped prior to the
  end of 2005.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Governmental Regulation</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's processing centers and
  manufacturing facilities are subject to many federal, state and local
  requirements relating to the protection of the environment.&nbsp; The Company
  believes that it operates its business in material compliance with all
  environmental laws and regulations, does not anticipate any material
  expenditures in order to meet environmental requirements and does not believe
  that future compliance with such laws and regulations will have a material
  adverse effect on its financial condition or results of operations.&nbsp; However,
  the Company could incur operating costs or capital expenditures in complying
  with more stringent environmental requirements in the future or with current
  requirements if they are applied to the Company's facilities in a way the
  Company does not anticipate.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's operations are also governed by
  many other laws and regulations.&nbsp; The Company believes that it is in material
  compliance with these laws and regulations and does not believe that future
  compliance with such laws and regulations will have a material adverse effect
  on its financial condition or results of operations.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Internet Information</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Copies of the Company's Annual Report on Form
  10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, Current Reports on Form 8-K, and
  amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) or
  15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are available free of charge
  through the Company's Web site (www.gibraltar1.com) as soon as reasonably
  practicable after the Company electronically files the material with, or
  furnishes it to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><u>
  Item 2.</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  <u>Description of Properties</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company maintains its corporate headquarters in Buffalo, New York and
  conducts business operations in facilities located throughout the United
  States</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company believesthat its primary existing facilities, listed below, and
  their equipment are effectively utilized, well maintained, in good condition
  and will be able to accommodate its capacity needs through 2005.</p>

        <td valign="top" style="width: 101; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in" height="24" align="left">

        Footage</u></td>

        &nbsp;</td>

    <tr>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 208; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in" height="19" align="left">
      <p class="MsoHeading8"><i>Corporate</i></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 303; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in" height="19" align="left">
      <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid">
      &nbsp;</td>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; * - Leased.&nbsp; All
  other facilities owned.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><u>
  Item 3.</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  <u>Legal Proceedings</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  From time to time, the Company is named a
  defendant in legal actions arising out of the normal course of business.&nbsp; The
  Company is not a party to any pending legal proceeding the resolution of which
  the management of the Company believes will have a material adverse effect on
  the Company's results of operations or financial condition or to any other
  pending legal proceedings other than ordinary, routine litigation incidental
  to its business.&nbsp; The Company maintains liability insurance against risks
  arising out of the normal course of business.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><u>
  Item 4.</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  <u>Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-autospace: none; margin-left: .5in">
  On October 26, 2004, at a Special Meeting of
  Stockholders, the Company's stockholders authorized an amendment to the
  Company's Certificate of Incorporation to change the name of the Company from
  Gibraltar Steel Corporation to Gibraltar Industries, Inc. The number of votes
  cast for, against, and withheld for this amendment were 28,584,052, 10,653 and
  537, respectively.&nbsp; The name change became effective on October 27, 2004.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  <u>PART II</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><u>
  Item 5.</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  <u>Market for Common Equity and Related Stockholder Matters</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">As of
  December 31, 2004, there were 122 shareholders of record of the Company's
  common stock.&nbsp; However, the Company believes that it has a significantly
  higher number of shareholders because of the number of shares that are held by
  nominees</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's common stock is traded in the over-the-counter market and quoted
  on the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation System -
  National Market System (&quot;NASDAQ&quot;) under the symbol &quot;ROCK.&quot;&nbsp; The following
  table sets forth the high and low sale prices per share for the Company's
  common stock for each quarter of 2004 and 2003 as reported on the NASDAQ
  National Market.&nbsp; Prices set forth below have been adjusted to reflect a
  three-for-two stock split effectuated in the form of a stock dividend paid on
  October 29, 2004.</p>

  </table>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Company declared dividends of $.030 per
  share in the first quarter of 2004, $.033 per share in the second and third
  quarters of 2004, and $.050 per share in the fourth quarter of 2004.&nbsp; The
  Company declared dividends of $.027 per share in the first quarter of 2003 and
  $.030 in each of the second, third and fourth quarters of 2003.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  Cash dividends are declared at the discretion
  of the Company's Board of Directors.&nbsp; The Board of Directors reviews the
  dividend quarterly and establishes the dividend rate based upon such factors
  as the Company's earnings, financial condition, capital requirements, debt
  covenant requirements and/or other relevant conditions.&nbsp; Although the Company
  expects to continue to declare and pay cash dividends on its common stock in
  the future if earnings are available, the Company cannot assure that either
  cash or stock dividends will be paid in the future or that, if paid, the
  dividends will be paid in the same amount or at the same frequency as paid in
  the past.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The following table summarizes information
  concerning securities authorized for issuance under the Company's stock option
  plans:</p>

      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; line-height: 14.0pt; page-break-after: avoid">
      &nbsp;</td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 58; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; line-height: 14.0pt; page-break-after: avoid">
      3,976</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in"><u>
  Item 7.</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  <u>Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
  Operations</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The following Management's Discussion and
  Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations should be read in
  conjunction with the Company's consolidated financial statements and notes
  thereto included in Item 8 of this Form 10-K.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  Overview
  </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The consolidated financial statements present
  the financial condition of the Company as of December 31, 2004 and 2003, and
  the consolidated results of operations and cash flows of the Company for the
  years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Company is organized into three reportable
  segments - Processed Metal Products, Building Products and Thermal
  Processing.&nbsp; The Company also held
  equity positions in two joint ventures as of December 31, 2004.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Processed Metal Products segment produces
  a wide variety of cold-rolled strip steel products, coated sheet steel
  products, powdered metal products and strapping products.&nbsp; This segment
  primarily serves the automotive industry's leaders, such as General Motors,
  Ford, Chrysler, and Honda. This segment also serves the &nbsp;automotive supply and
  commercial and residential metal
  building industry, as well as the power
  and hand tool and hardware industries. &nbsp;During 2004, the Company strengthened
  its Processed Metal Products segment through its acquisition of&nbsp; SCM Metal
  Products, Inc. (acquired June 1, 2004) which added approximately $34.8 million
  to the Company's consolidated net sales for 2004.&nbsp; The automotive market is a
  very important part of the Company's Processed Metal Products segment. In
  2005, the Company plans to continue its longstanding relationships with the
  domestic automotive manufacturers, as well as enhance its present
  relationships with the transplant automobile manufacturers and their
  suppliers. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Building Products segment processes sheet
  steel to produce a wide variety of building and construction products. This
  segment's products are sold to major retail home centers, such as The Home
  Depot, Lowe's, Menards, and Wal-Mart. During 2004, the Company strengthened
  its position in the Building Products market through the acquisitions of
  Renown (acquired January 1, 2004) and Portals Plus (acquired August 13, 2004).
  These strategic acquisitions enabled the Company to broaden its geographic
  markets, solidify product offerings, strengthen customer relationships and
  added approximately $15.2 million to the Company's consolidated net sales for
  2004. &nbsp;In 2005, the Company believes
  the ongoing trend of increased use of metal building products will continue
  because of favorable environmental characteristics, cost efficiency and
  architectural design enhancements. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .5in">
  The Thermal Processing segment provides a wide
  array of processes which refine the metallurgical properties of customer-owned
  metal products for a variety of consumer and industrial applications where
  critical performance characteristics are required. This segment services such
  customers as General Motors, Ford, Eaton Corporation, Dana Corporation, and
  International Truck.&nbsp; &nbsp;In 2005, the Company believes the growing trend in the
  outsourcing of thermal processing operations will continue and
  that its thermal processing facilities are
  strategically located to meet the needs of customers from a geographically
  diverse base of operations. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The following table sets forth the Company's
  net sales by reportable segment for the period ending December 31:</p>
  <table class="MsoTableGrid" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; margin-left: 45.0pt">

      <td width="112" valign="top" style="width: 83.85pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">

      645,114</td>
