  </div>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
  The accompanying notes are integral part of
  these consolidated financial statements</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
  &nbsp;</div>
<div class="Section3">
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align: center; page-break-after: avoid">
  <u>GIBRALTAR INDUSTRIES, INC.<br>
  <br>
  NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Principles of
  Consolidation</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The consolidated
  financial statements include the accounts of Gibraltar Industries, Inc. and
  subsidiaries (the Company).&nbsp; All significant intercompany accounts and
  transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Use of
  Estimates</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The preparation
  of the consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting
  principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires
  management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported
  in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.&nbsp; Actual
  results could differ from those estimates.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Revenue
  Recognition</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Revenue is
  recognized when products are shipped or service is provided, the customer
  takes ownership and assumes the risk of loss, collection of the relevant
  receivable is probable, persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists and the
  sales price is fixed or determinable. &nbsp;Sales returns, allowances and customer
  incentives are treated as reductions to sales and are provided for based on
  historical experience and current estimates.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Promotional
  Allowances</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company
  promotes its branded products through cooperative advertising programs with
  retailers. Retailers also are offered in-store promotional allowances and
  rebates based on sales volumes. Promotion costs (including allowances and
  rebates) incurred during the year are expensed to interim periods in relation
  to revenues and are recorded as a reduction of net sales.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Cash and Cash
  Equivalents</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Cash and cash
  equivalents include cash on hand, checking accounts and all highly liquid
  investments with a maturity of three months or less.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Accounts
  Receivable</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Accounts
  receivable are recorded at the invoiced amount and do not bear interest. The
  allowance for doubtful accounts is the Company's best estimate of the amount
  of probable credit losses in the Company's existing accounts receivable. The
  Company determines the allowance based on a number of factors, including
  historical experience, credit worthiness of customers and current market and
  economic conditions. The Company reviews the allowance for doubtful accounts
  on a regular basis. Account balances are charged against the allowance after
  all means of collection have been exhausted and the potential for recovery is
  considered remote. The Company does not have any off-balance sheet exposure
  related to its customers.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Accounts
  receivable are expected to be collected within one year and are net of the
  allowance for doubtful accounts of $3,090,000 and $2,610,000 at December 31,
  2004 and 2003, respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Inventories</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Inventories are
  valued at the lower of cost or market.&nbsp; The cost basis of the inventory is
  determined on a first-in, first-out basis using either actual costs or a
  standard cost methodology which approximates actual cost.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Property,
  Plant and Equipment</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Property, plant
  and equipment are stated at cost and depreciated over their estimated useful
  lives using the straight-line method. Expenditures that extend the useful
  lives of assets are capitalized, while repair and maintenance costs are
  expensed as incurred. The estimated useful lives of land improvements and
  buildings and building improvements is 15 to 40 years, while machinery and
  equipment is 3 to 20 years.&nbsp; Accelerated methods are used for income tax
  purposes.&nbsp; Depreciation expense aggregated $23,653,000, $21,644,000 and
  $19,927,000 in 2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Interest is
  capitalized in connection with construction of qualified assets.&nbsp; Interest of
  $258,000, $156,000 and $105,000 was capitalized in 2004, 2003 and 2002,
  respectively. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  <u>Acquisition Related Assets and Liabilities</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  Accounting for the acquisition of a business as a purchase transaction
  requires an allocation of the purchase price to the assets acquired and the
  liabilities assumed in the transaction at their respective estimated fair
  values. The most difficult estimations of individual fair values are those
  involving long-lived assets, such as property, plant and equipment and
  intangible assets. We use all available information to make these fair value
  determinations and, for major business acquisitions, engage an independent
  valuation specialist to assist in the fair value determination of the acquired
  long-lived assets. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Goodwill and
  Other Intangible Assets</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  The Company tests goodwill for impairment at
  the reporting unit level on an annual basis during the fourth quarter or more
  frequently if an event occurs or circumstances change that indicate that the
  fair value of a reporting unit could be below its carrying amount. The
  impairment test consists of comparing the fair value of a reporting unit,
  determined using discounted cash flows, with its carrying amount including
  goodwill, and, if the carrying amount of the reporting unit exceeds its fair
  value, comparing the implied fair value of goodwill with its carrying amount.
  An impairment loss would be recognized for the carrying amount of goodwill in
  excess of its implied fair value.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  Acquired identifiable intangible assets are
  recorded at cost.&nbsp; Identifiable intangible assets with finite useful lives are
  amortized over their estimated useful lives.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>
  Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Long-lived
  assets, including acquired identifiable intangible assets, are reviewed for
  impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the
  carrying amount of those assets may not be recoverable.&nbsp; The Company uses
  undiscounted cash flows to determine whether impairment exists and measures
  any impairment loss using discounted cash flows.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Investments in
  Partnerships</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company's
  investments in partnerships are accounted for using the equity method of
  accounting, under which the Company's share of the earnings of the partnership
  is recognized in income as earned, and distributions are credited against the
  investment when received. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Equity method
  goodwill arises when the Company's investment in the partnership exceeds its
  applicable share of the fair market value of the partnership's net assets at
  the date the partnership was formed. In accordance with SFAS 142<i>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</i>, equity method goodwill is not
  amortized or tested for impairment in accordance with this standard. The
  Company reviews the equity method goodwill in accordance with Accounting
  Principles Board Opinion No. 18, <i>The Equity Method of Accounting for
  Investments in Common Stock</i> (APB Opinion No. 18), under which the Company
  would recognize an impairment loss when there is a loss in the value of the
  equity method investment which is deemed to be other than a temporary
  decline.&nbsp; No impairments were recognized in the years ended December 31, 2004,
  2003 and 2002.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Interest Rate
  Exchange Agreements</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Interest rate
  swap agreements are used by the Company in the management of interest rate
  risk.&nbsp; The interest rate swaps are not used for trading purposes and are
  accounted for as cash flow hedges under SFAS 133, <i>Accounting for Derivative
  Instruments and Hedging Activities</i>. The Company has determined that there
  is no ineffectiveness in these hedging relationships based on the criteria set
  forth in SFAS 133. The fair values of interest rate swap agreements are
  recognized as other current liabilities and aggregated $232,000 and $2,387,000
  at December 31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; Gains or losses from changes in
  the fair value of the swap agreements are recorded, net of taxes, as
  components of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income or Loss.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Translation of
  Foreign Currency</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The assets and
  liabilities of the Company's foreign subsidiaries are translated into U.S.
  dollars at the rate of exchange in effect at the balance sheet date.&nbsp; Income
  and expense items are translated at the average exchange rates prevailing
  during the period.&nbsp; Gains and losses resulting from foreign currency
  transactions are recognized currently in income and those resulting from the
  translation of financial statements are accumulated as a separate component of
  comprehensive income net of related taxes.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Shareholders'
  Equity</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">During 2004 and
  2003, the Company declared dividends of $4,335,000 and $2,962,000,
  respectively, of which $1,484,000 and $869,000 are accrued at December 31,
  2004 and 2003, respectively. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company
  reacquired 12,000 shares and 6,000 shares of forfeited restricted common stock
  in 2004 and 2003 respectively, at a cost of $.01 per share and reduced
  additional paid-in capital for an amount equal to the gross unvested portion
  of the restricted stock award at the date of forfeiture. These reacquired
  shares and related cost are reflected as treasury stock in the consolidated
  balance sheets at December 31, 2004 and 2003. &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Comprehensive
  Income </u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Comprehensive
  income includes net income as well as accumulated other comprehensive income
  (loss). The Company's accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) consists
  of unrealized gains and losses on interest rate swaps, minimum pension
  liability and foreign currency translation adjustments, which are recorded net
  of related taxes.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>
  Net Income Per Share</u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .2in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  Share and per share data for all periods
  presented have been adjusted for the three-for-two stock split further
  discussed at Note 12.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Basic net income
  per share equals net income divided by the weighted average shares outstanding
  during the year.&nbsp; The computation of diluted net income per share includes all
  dilutive common stock equivalents in the weighted average shares outstanding.
  A reconciliation between basic net income per share and diluted net income per
  share for the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 is displayed in
  Note 13.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Income Taxes</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The consolidated
  financial statements of the Company have been prepared using the asset and
  liability approach in accounting for income taxes which requires the
  recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax
  consequences of temporary differences between the carrying amounts and the tax
  bases of other assets and liabilities.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Fair Market
  Value Disclosures</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">SFAS 107, <i>
  Disclosures About Fair Market Value of Financial Instruments, </i>defines the
  fair value of a financial instrument as the amount at which the instrument
  could be exchanged in a current transaction between willing parties.&nbsp; The
  Company's cash and cash equivalents and accounts receivable are stated at cost
  which approximates fair value at December 31, 2004.&nbsp; The fair value of the
  Company's debt approximated $319,029,000 at December 31, 2004.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Fair market value
  estimates are made at a specific point in time based on relevant market
  information about the financial instrument. These estimates are subjective in
  nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and,
  therefore, cannot be determined with precision. Changes in assumptions could
  significantly affect these estimates.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Stock Based
  Compensation</u></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><i>Stock options<br>
  </i>In December 2002,
  the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued SFAS 148, <i>Accounting
  for Stock-Based Compensation-Transition and Disclosure</i> which amends SFAS
  123, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</i>.&nbsp; SFAS 148 provides
  alternative methods of transition for a voluntary change to the fair value
  based method of accounting for stock-based employee compensation and amends
  the disclosure requirements of SFAS 123 to require disclosures in both the
  annual and interim financial statements about the method of accounting for
  stock-based employee compensation and the effect of the method used on
  reported results.&nbsp; As allowed by SFAS 123, the Company follows the disclosure
  requirements of SFAS 123 and SFAS 148, but continues to account for its stock
  options using the intrinsic value-based method of accounting as prescribed by
  APB Opinion No. 25, <i>Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees</i> (APB
  Opinion No. 25).&nbsp; Accordingly, no compensation cost has been recognized for
  the stock option plans, as stock options granted under these plans have an
  exercise price equal to 100% of the market price of the underlying stock on
  the date of grant.&nbsp; The Company's stock option plans are discussed in more
  detail in Note 14.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><i>Restricted
  stock plan<br>
  </i>The Company has a
  restricted stock plan for the grant of restricted stock awards to employees
  and non-employee directors at a purchase price of $.01 per share. Upon
  issuance of the restricted shares, a charge equivalent to the market value of
  the shares on the date of grant less the purchase price of $.01 per share is
  charged to shareholders' equity (net of applicable tax effects), as unearned
  compensation (a contra equity account) and is amortized on a straight-line
  basis over the related share restriction period.&nbsp; The Company's restricted
  stock plan is discussed in more detail in Note 15.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The following
  table illustrates the pro forma effect on net income and net income per share,
  had the Company used the &nbsp;Black-Scholes option pricing model to calculate the
  fair value of stock based employee compensation pursuant to the provisions of
  SFAS 123 and SFAS 148 (in thousands, except per share data):</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in" align="center">
  Year Ended December 31, </p>

      <p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</td>
    </tr>
    <tr style="height: 13.75pt">
      <td valign="top" style="width: 318; height: 17; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp; </td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 8; height: 17; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">

      $</td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 70; height: 20; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      1.09</td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 43; height: 20; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      $</td>
      <td colspan="2" valign="top" style="width: 92; height: 20; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;.98</td>
    </tr>
    </table>
    </center>
  </div>
  <p style="margin-left: 0.5in">
      The fair values and assumptions used in the Black-Scholes option pricing
      model are as follows:</p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><u>Recent
  Accounting&nbsp; Pronouncements</u></p>
  <p style="margin-left: .5in">The Financial
  Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Statement of Financial Accounting
  Standard (SFAS) No. 123 (Revised 2004) (SFAS No. 123R), <i>Share-Based Payment</i>,
  in December 2004.&nbsp; SFAS No. 123R is a revision of FASB Statement 123, <i>
  Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</i> and supersedes APB Opinion No. 25,
  <i>Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees</i> and its related implementation
  guidance. The Statement focuses primarily on accounting for transactions in
  which an entity obtains employee services in share-based payment transactions.
  SFAS No. 123R requires a public entity to measure the cost of employee
  services received in exchange for an award of equity instruments based on the
  grant-date fair value of the award (with limited exceptions). That cost will
  be recognized over the period during which an employee is required to provide
  service in exchange for the award. This statement is effective as of the
  beginning of the first interim or annual reporting period that begins after
  June 15, 2005 and the Company will adopt the standard in the third quarter of
  fiscal 2005. The Company has not determined the impact, if any, that this
  statement will have on its consolidated financial position or results of
  operations. </p>
  <p style="margin-left: .5in">In December&nbsp;2004,
  the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;153, <i>Exchanges of Nonmonetary Assets-An Amendment
  of APB Opinion No. 29, Accounting for Nonmonetary Transactions</i> (SFAS 153).
  SFAS&nbsp;153 eliminates the exception from fair value measurement for nonmonetary
  exchanges of similar productive assets in paragraph&nbsp;21(b) of APB Opinion
  No.&nbsp;29, <i>Accounting for Nonmonetary Transactions</i>, and replaces it with
  an exception for exchanges that do not have commercial substance. SFAS&nbsp;153
  specifies that a nonmonetary exchange has commercial substance if the future
  cash flows of the entity are expected to change significantly as a result of
  the exchange. SFAS&nbsp;153 is effective for nonmonetary asset exchanges occurring
  in fiscal periods beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2005 and is required to be adopted
  by the Company for such exchanges in the third quarter of fiscal 2005.&nbsp; The
  Company is currently evaluating the effect that the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;153 will
  have on its consolidated results of operations and financial condition but
  does not expect it to have a material impact. </p>
  <p style="margin-left: .5in">In November 2004,
  the FASB issued SFAS No. 151, <i>Inventory Costs, an amendment of ARB No. 43,
  Chapter 4</i>, &nbsp;(SFAS 151) which clarifies the types of costs that should be
  expensed rather than capitalized as inventory. This statement also clarifies
  the circumstances under which fixed overhead costs associated with operating
  facilities involved in inventory processing should be capitalized. The
  provisions of SFAS No. 151 are effective for fiscal years beginning after June
  15, 2005 and the Company will adopt this standard in the first quarter of
  fiscal 2006.&nbsp; The Company has not determined the impact, if any, that this
  statement will have on its consolidated financial position or results of
  operations.&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
  <p style="margin-left: .5in">In May 2004, the
  FASB released FASB Staff Position No. FAS 106-2 <i>Accounting and Disclosure
  Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and
  Modernization Act of 2003</i> (FSP 106-2).&nbsp; The Medicare Prescription Drug
  Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the &quot;Medicare Act&quot;) was enacted
  December&nbsp;8, 2003. On January 21, 2005 the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid
  Services released the final regulations for implementing the Medicare Act.&nbsp;
  FSP 106-2 provides authoritative guidance on accounting for the federal
  subsidy specified in the Medicare Act. The Medicare Act provides for a federal
  subsidy equal to 28% of certain prescription drug claims for sponsors of
  retiree health care plans with drug benefits that are at least actuarially
  equivalent to those to be offered under Medicare Part&nbsp;D, beginning in 2006.
  The Company was unable to conclude whether the benefits provided by the plan
  are actuarially equivalent to Medicare Part D under the Act, and therefore we
  have not determined whether we will need to amend our plan, nor what effect
  the Act will have on our consolidated financial position, results of
  operations or cash flows.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">&nbsp;In December
  2003, the FASB issued SFAS 132 (revised 2003), <i>Employer's Disclosures About
  Pensions and Other Postretirement Benefits</i>. SFAS 132 (revised 2003),
  revises employers' disclosures about pension plans and other postretirement
  benefit plans. SFAS 132 (revised 2003), does not change the measurement and
  recognition of those plans required by SFAS 87, <i>Employers' Accounting for
  Pensions</i>, SFAS 88, <i>Employers' Accounting for Settlements and
  Curtailments of Defined Benefit Pension Plans and for Termination Benefits</i>,
  and SFAS 106, <i>Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than
  Pensions</i>. SFAS 132 (revised 2003), retains the original disclosure
  requirements of SFAS 132 and requires additional expanded annual and interim
  disclosures to those in the original SFAS 132 about the assets, obligations,
  cash flows, and net periodic benefit costs of defined benefit pension plans
  and other defined benefit </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">postretirement
  benefit plans. &nbsp;&nbsp;The adoption of this Statement is required for financial
  statements with fiscal years ending after December 15, 2003. Implementation of
  SFAS 132 (revised 2003) did not have a material impact on the Company's
  consolidated financial statements. The revised disclosure requirements of this
  Statement are reflected in Notes 8 and 9 of the consolidated financial
  statements included in Item 8 herein.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In May 2003, the
  FASB issued SFAS 150, <i>Accounting for Certain Financial Instruments with
  Characteristics of both Liabilities and Equity</i>. SFAS 150 establishes
  standards for how an issuer classifies and measures certain financial
  instruments with characteristics of both liabilities and equity.&nbsp; SFAS 150
  applies specifically to a number of financial instruments that companies have
  historically presented within their financial statements either as equity or
  between the liabilities section and the equity section, rather than as
  liabilities.&nbsp; SFAS 150 is effective for financial instruments entered into or
  modified after May 31, 2003, and otherwise is effective at the beginning of
  the first interim period beginning after June 15, 2003.&nbsp; Implementation of
  SFAS 150 did not have a material impact on the Company's consolidated
  financial statements.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In April 2003,
  the FASB issued SFAS 149, <i>Amendment of Statement 133 on Derivative
  Instruments and Hedging Activities.</i> SFAS 149 clarifies the accounting for
  derivatives, amending the previously issued SFAS 133, <i>Accounting for
  Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities.</i>&nbsp; SFAS 149 clarifies under
  what circumstances a contract with an initial net investment meets the
  characteristics of a derivative, amends the definition of any underlying
  contract, and clarifies when a derivative contains a financing components in
  order to increase the comparability of accounting practices under SFAS 133.&nbsp;
  SFAS 149 is effective for contracts entered into or modified after June 30,
  2003.&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS 149 did not have a material impact on the
  Company's consolidated financial statements.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In December 2003,
  the FASB issued FIN 46(R), <i>Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities.</i>&nbsp;
  This interpretation of Accounting Research Bulletin No. 51, <i>Consolidated
  Financial Statements</i>, replaced FIN 46 and addresses consolidation of
  variable interest entities. FIN 46(R) requires certain variable interest
  entities to be consolidated by the primary beneficiary if the entity does not
  effectively disperse risks among the parties involved. The provisions of FIN
  46(R) are effective immediately for those variable interest entities created
  after January 31, 2003.&nbsp; The provisions are effective for financial statements
  issued for the first interim or annual period ending after December 15, 2003
  for those variable interests held prior to February 1, 2003.&nbsp; The adoption of
  this Interpretation did not have any effect on the Company's financial
  position or results of operations.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In December 2002,
  the FASB issued SFAS 148, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation -
  Transition and Disclosure, an Amendment of SFAS No. 123.</i>&nbsp; SFAS 148 amends
  SFAS 123, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</i>, to provide
  alternative methods of transition for a voluntary change to the fair value
  based method of accounting for stock-based employee compensation.&nbsp; In
  addition, SFAS 148 amends the disclosure requirements of SFAS 123 to require
  more prominent and more frequent disclosures in the financial statements
  regarding the effects of stock-based compensation.&nbsp; SFAS 148 is effective for
  financial statements for fiscal years ending after December 15, 2002,
  including certain amendments to required disclosures related to stock-based
  compensation included in condensed financial statements for interim periods
  beginning after December 15, 2002.&nbsp; Adoption of SFAS 148 did not have a
  material impact on the Company's financial position, results of operations or
  cash flows.&nbsp; For further discussion of the Company's stock-based compensation
  arrangements, see Note 1 of the Company's consolidated financial statements
  included in Item 8 herein.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In November 2002,
  the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No. 45, <i>Guarantor's Accounting and
  Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect Guarantees of
  Indebtedness of Others </i>(FIN 45). FIN 45 requires the fair-value
  measurement and recognition of a liability for the issuance of certain
  guarantees issued or modified on January 1, 2003 or after.&nbsp; Implementation of
  the fair-value measurement and recognition provisions of FIN 45 did not have a
  material impact on the Company's financial position or results of operations.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In June 2002, the
  FASB issued SFAS 146, <i>Accounting for Exit or Disposal Activities.</i> SFAS
  146 requires that a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal
  activity be recognized when the liability is incurred.&nbsp; The provisions of SFAS
  146 are effective for exit or disposal activities that were initiated after
  December 31, 2002 and did not have a material impact on the Company's
  financial position or results of operations.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Acquisitions</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On July 1, 2002,
  the Company purchased all of the outstanding capital stock of B&amp;W Thermal
  Processing (1975) Limited (B&amp;W) for approximately $9,200,000.&nbsp; The purchase
  price consisted of approximately $8,500,000 payable in cash and 48,982 shares
  of the Company's common stock valued at $700,000, including 18,858 treasury
  shares.&nbsp; B&amp;W, located in Ontario, Canada, specializes in commercial thermal
  processing.&nbsp; The results of operations of B&amp;W (included in the Company's
  Thermal Processing segment) have been included in the Company's consolidated
  financial statements since the date of acquisition.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On April 1, 2003,
  the Company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Construction Metals, Inc.
  (Construction Metals).&nbsp; Construction Metals is headquartered in Ontario,
  California and is a manufacturer of a wide array of building and construction
  products that are sold to retail and wholesale customers throughout the
  western United States.&nbsp; The acquisition of Construction Metals allowed the
  Company to eliminate a competitor and strengthen its distribution network in
  the building products market.&nbsp; The results of operations of Construction
  Metals (included in the Company's Building Products segment) have been
  included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the date of
  acquisition.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The aggregate
  purchase consideration for the acquisition of Construction Metals was
  approximately $29,185,000, which was comprised of approximately $11,685,000 in
  cash, including direct acquisition costs, and $17,500,000 of unsecured
  subordinated debt, payable to the former owners of Construction Metals.&nbsp; The
  purchase price was allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed
  based upon respective fair market values.&nbsp; The fair market values of the
  property, plant and equipment and identifiable intangible assets were
  determined with the assistance of an independent valuation.&nbsp; The identifiable
  intangible assets consisted of non-competition agreements with an aggregate
  fair market value of approximately $830,000 (5-year weighted average useful
  life).&nbsp; The excess consideration over such fair value was recorded as goodwill
  and aggregated approximately $19,546,000, none of which is deductible for tax
  purposes.&nbsp; The allocation of purchase consideration to the assets acquired and
  liabilities assumed is as follows (in thousands):</p>

      <td width="73" valign="top" style="width: 55.05pt; height: 15.05pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">As part of the
  purchase agreement between the Company and the former owners of Construction
  Metals, the Company may be required to pay additional consideration if certain
  net sales levels as defined in the purchase agreement are achieved during the
  period from acquisition up to March 31, 2006.&nbsp; During the second quarter of
  2004, a payment of $345,000 was made as a result of the net sales achieved.&nbsp;
  This payment was recorded as additional goodwill.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On May 1, 2003,
  the Company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Air Vent Inc. (Air
  Vent).&nbsp; Air Vent is headquartered in Dallas, Texas and is primarily engaged in
  the manufacture and distribution of a complete line of ventilation products
  and accessories.&nbsp; The acquisition of Air Vent allowed the Company to eliminate
  a competitor and strengthen its position in the building products market.&nbsp; The
  results of operations of Air Vent (included in the Company's Building Products
  segment) have been included in the Company's consolidated financial statements
  since the date of acquisition.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The aggregate
  purchase consideration for the acquisition of Air Vent was approximately
  $117,798,000, which was comprised of approximately $75,503,000 in cash,
  including direct acquisition costs, and $42,295,000 of unsecured subordinated
  debt, payable to the former owner of Air Vent.&nbsp; The purchase price was
  allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based upon respective
  fair market values. The fair market values of the property, plant and
  equipment and identifiable intangible assets were determined with the
  assistance of an independent valuation.&nbsp; The identifiable intangible assets
  consisted of non-competition agreements with an aggregate fair market value of
  approximately $1,400,000 (10-year weighted average useful life). The excess
  consideration over such fair value was recorded as goodwill and aggregated
  approximately $103,104,000. The allocation of purchase consideration to the
  assets acquired and liabilities assumed is as follows (in thousands):</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company and
  the former owner of Air Vent have made a joint election under Internal Revenue
  Code (IRC) Section 338(h)(10) which allows the Company to treat the stock
  purchase as an asset purchase for tax purposes.&nbsp; As a result of the 338(h)(10)
  election, goodwill in the amount of $103,104,000 is expected to be fully
  deductible for tax purposes. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On January 6,
  2004, the Company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Renown Specialties
  Company Ltd. (Renown).&nbsp; Renown is headquartered in Thornhill, Ontario and is a
  designer, manufacturer and distributor of construction hardware products in
  Canada. The acquisition of Renown served to broaden the Company's product
  lines and strengthen its existing position in the building products market.
  The results of operations of Renown (included in the Company's Building
  Products segment) have been included in the Company's consolidated financial
  statements since the date of acquisition. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The aggregate
  purchase consideration for the acquisition of Renown was approximately
  $6,370,000 which was comprised solely of cash, including direct acquisition
  costs.&nbsp; The purchase price was allocated to the assets acquired and
  liabilities assumed based upon respective fair market values.&nbsp; The fair market
  values of the property, plant and equipment and identifiable intangible assets
  were determined with the assistance of an independent valuation.&nbsp; The
  identifiable intangible assets consisted of non-competition agreements with an
  aggregate fair market value of $35,000 (5-year weighted average useful life),
  trademarks / trade names with an aggregate fair market value of $100,000
  (2-year weighted average useful life), and customer relationships with an
  aggregate fair market value of $80,000 (5-year weighted average useful life).&nbsp;
  See Note 3 for further discussion.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The excess
  consideration over such fair value was recorded as goodwill and aggregated
  approximately $3,701,000, none of which is deductible for tax purposes. The
  allocation of purchase consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities
  assumed is as follows (in thousands):</p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On June 1, 2004,
  the Company acquired the net assets of SCM Metal Products, Inc. (SCM).&nbsp; SCM is
  headquartered in Research Triangle Park, North Carolina and manufactures,
  markets and distributes non-ferrous metal powder products to customers in a
  number of different industries, including the automotive, aerospace,
  electronics and consumer products industries.&nbsp; The results of operations of
  SCM (included in the Company's Processed Metal Products segment) have been
  included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the date of
  acquisition.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The aggregate
  purchase consideration for the acquisition of SCM was approximately
  $42,882,000 in cash and acquisition costs.&nbsp; The purchase price was allocated
  to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based upon respective fair
  market values.&nbsp; The fair market values of the property, plant and equipment
  and identifiable intangible assets were determined with the assistance of an
  independent valuation.&nbsp; The identifiable intangible assets consisted of
  trademarks/trade names with an aggregate value of $440,000 (indeterminable
  useful life), unpatented technology with a value of $900,000 (10-year weighted
  average useful life) and customer relationships with a value of $5,560,000
  (15-year weighted average useful life).&nbsp; See Note 7 for further discussion.&nbsp;
  The excess consideration over such fair value was recorded as goodwill and
  aggregated approximately $4,238,000, which is fully deductible for tax
  purposes.&nbsp; The allocation of purchase consideration to the assets acquired and
  liabilities assumed is as follows (in thousands):</p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On August 13,
  2004 the Company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Portals Plus
  Incorporated and its affiliated companies, Roofing Products &amp; Systems
  Corporation and J.L.R. Services, Inc. (Portals Plus).&nbsp; Portals Plus is
  headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, and manufactures a diverse line of roofing
  products.&nbsp; The acquisition of Portals Plus served to strengthen the Company's
  position in the roofing products markets.&nbsp; The results of operations of
  Portals Plus (included in the Company's Building Products segment) have been
  included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the date of
  acquisition.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  The aggregate purchase consideration of Portals Plus was approximately
  $15,167,000, subject to final adjustment for payment of the sellers tax
  liability, and was comprised solely of cash, including direct acquisition
  costs.&nbsp; The purchase price was allocated to the assets acquired and
  liabilities assumed based upon respective fair values.&nbsp; The fair market
  values of the property, plant and equipment and identifiable intangible assets
  were determined with the assistance of an independent valuation.&nbsp; The
  identifiable intangible assets consisted of customer relationships with a
  value of $1,830,000 (10-year weighted average useful life), and patents with a
  value of $21,000 (18-year weighted average useful life).&nbsp; The excess
  consideration over such fair value was recorded as goodwill and aggregated
  approximately $9,396,000.&nbsp; The preliminary
  allocation of purchase consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities
  assumed is as follows (in thousands):</p>
  <table class="MsoTableGrid" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; margin-left: 1.25in">
    <tr style="height: 14.75pt">
      <td width="283" valign="top" style="width: 2.95in; height: 14.75pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 9.0pt">
      Working capital</td>
      <td width="72" valign="top" style="width: .75in; height: 14.75pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid">
      $</td>
      <td width="120" valign="top" style="width: 1.25in; height: 14.75pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">

    </tr>

      15,167</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  The Company and the former owner of Portals Plus have made a joint election
  under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 338(h)(10) which allows the Company
  to treat the stock purchase as an asset purchase for tax purposes.&nbsp; As a
  result of the 338(h)(10) election, goodwill in the amount of $9,396,000 is
  expected to be fully deductible for tax purposes.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  The following unaudited pro forma financial information presents the combined results of
  operations as if the acquisitions had occurred at the beginning of each period
  presented.&nbsp; The pro forma information includes certain adjustments, including
  depreciation expense, interest expense and certain other adjustments, together
  with related income tax effects.&nbsp; The pro forma amounts may not be indicative
  of the results that actually would have been achieved had the acquisitions
  occurred as of January 1, 2003 and are not necessarily indicative of future
  results of the combined companies (in thousands, except per share date):</p>

      <td width="408" style="border: medium none" height="20">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="19" style="border: medium none" height="20">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="3" style="border: medium none" height="20"></td>
      <td width="78" style="border: medium none" height="19">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="20" style="border: medium none" height="20">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="31" style="border: medium none" height="20">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="84" style="border: medium none" height="19">&nbsp;</td>

  </table>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .2in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <br>
  On February 16, 2004, the Company acquired the
  net assets of Covert Operations, Inc. (Covert), a manufacturer of epoxies and
  crack injection systems for concrete and masonry. The aggregate purchase
  consideration of Covert was approximately $1,336,000, including direct
  acquisition costs. The acquisition of Covert resulted in approximately
  $640,000 in goodwill, which is fully deductible for tax purposes.&nbsp; The
  acquisition of Covert is not considered to be material to the Company's
  consolidated results of operations. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; GOODWILL AND RELATED INTANGIBLE ASSETS</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><i>Goodwill</i></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The changes in
  the carrying amount of goodwill by reportable segment for the years ended
  December 31, 2004 and 2003 are as follows (in thousands):</p>

      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 2.2pt">
      285,927</td>
    </tr>

    <tr height="0">
      <td width="261" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="4" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="20" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="109" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="1" style="border: medium none"></td>
      <td width="24" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="1" style="border: medium none"></td>
      <td width="83" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="4" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="20" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="3" style="border: medium none"></td>
      <td width="94" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="3" style="border: medium none"></td>
      <td width="19" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="67" style="border: medium none"></td>
      <td width="36" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
      <td width="4" style="border: medium none">&nbsp;</td>
    </tr>

  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">As described in
  Note 6, the Company entered into a joint venture with Duferco Farrell
  Corporation in 2003, in which the Company acquired a 50% partnership interest
  in Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC. The Company's investment in Gibraltar DFC
  Strip Steel, LLC. (included in the Company's Processed Metals Products
  segment) exceeded its applicable share of the fair market value of the
  partnership's net assets at the date the partnership was formed and resulted
  in equity method goodwill of approximately $11,320,000. There was no
  impairment associated with this equity method goodwill in 2004 or 2003.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><i>Intangible
  Assets</i></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .2in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  Intangible assets related to the Company's
  acquisitions are included as part of the total other assets on the Company's
  condensed consolidated balance sheet.&nbsp; Intangible assets subject to
  amortization at December 31 are as follows (in thousands):</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .2in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">

      $</td>

      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      269,019</td>
      <td width="43" valign="top" style="width: .45in; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      $</td>
      <td width="77" valign="top" style="width: .8in; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      250,029</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; INVESTMENTS IN PARTNERSHIPS</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company has a
  31% partnership interest in a steel pickling joint venture with Samuel
  Manu-Tech, Inc.&nbsp; The partnership provides a steel cleaning process called
  pickling to steel mills and steel processors. The investment is included in
  the Company's Processed Metal Products segment and is accounted for using the
  equity method of accounting. &nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's investment in the partnership was
  approximately $3,127,000 and $3,454,000 at December 31, 2004 and 2003,
  respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In December 2003,
  the Company entered into a joint venture with Duferco Farrell Corporation, in
  which the Company acquired a 50% partnership interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip
  Steel, LLC. The joint venture was formed for the purpose of manufacturing and
  distributing cold-rolled strip steel products.&nbsp; The investment is accounted
  for using the equity method of accounting.&nbsp; The Company's proportionate share
  in the net assets of the joint venture was approximately $5,084,000 and
  $1,590,000 at December 31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">

      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;</td>
      <td width="43" valign="top" style="width: .45in; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;</td>
      <td width="77" valign="top" style="width: .8in; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;</td>
      <td width="43" valign="top" style="width: .45in; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;</td>
      <td width="77" valign="top" style="width: .8in; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td width="389" valign="top" style="width: 4.05in; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Total long-term debt</td>
      <td width="43" valign="top" style="width: .45in; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      $</td>
      <td width="77" valign="top" style="width: .8in; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      295,347</td>
      <td width="43" valign="top" style="width: .45in; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      $</td>
      <td width="77" valign="top" style="width: .8in; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      222,402</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's revolving credit facility of
  $290,000,000 is collateralized by the Company's accounts receivable,
  inventories, and personal property and
  equipment, and is committed through
  June 2007 and contains a $10,000,000 expansion feature at the Company's
  option, subject to approval by the participating financial institutions.&nbsp; A
  commitment fee of 30 basis points of the unused portion of the facility is
  payable quarterly.&nbsp; This facility has various interest rate options, which are
  no greater than the bank's prime rate (5.25% at December 31, 2004).&nbsp; In
  addition, the Company may enter into interest rate exchange agreements (swaps)
  to manage interest costs and exposure to changing interest rates.&nbsp; At December
  31, 2004, the Company had interest rate swap agreements outstanding which
  expire in 2005 and effectively converted $20,000,000 of floating rate debt to
  fixed rates ranging from 7.22% to 7.70%.&nbsp; Additional borrowings under the
  revolving credit facility of&nbsp; $130,000,000 and $75,000,000 had an interest
  rate of LIBOR plus a fixed rate at December 31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp;
  &nbsp;There were additional borrowings of $7,636,000 at the prime rate at December
  31, 2004.&nbsp; The weighted average interest rate of these borrowings was 4.59%
  and 3.55% at December 31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp;
  $7,725,000 of standby letters of credit have
  been issued under the revolving credit agreement to third parties on behalf of
  the Company at December 31, 2004.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; These letters of credit reduce the amount
  otherwise available. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  In June 2004, the Company entered into a
  $75,000,000 private placement of debt with The Prudential Insurance Company of
  America.&nbsp; This senior secured note bears interest at 5.75% annually and has a
  seven year term.&nbsp; The Company drew down $55,000,000 which was outstanding
  at&nbsp;December 31, 2004, and will draw down the remaining $20,000,000 at
  specified dates and amounts which coincide with the expiration of the interest
  rate swap agreements currently outstanding under the Company's existing
  revolving credit facility.&nbsp; The initial $55,000,000 borrowing under this note
  was used to pay down a portion of the existing revolving credit facility.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's acquisition notes payable
  consists of debt incurred in connection with the 2003 acquisitions of
  Construction Metals and Air Vent.&nbsp; In connection with the acquisition of
  Construction Metals, the Company entered into two unsecured subordinated notes
  payable each in the amount of $8,750,000 (aggregate total of $17,500,000).
  These notes are payable to the two former owners of Construction Metals and
  are considered related party in nature due to the former owners' current
  employment relationship with the Company.&nbsp; These notes are payable in equal
  annual principal installments of $2,917,000 per note on April 1, with the
  final principal payment due on April 1, 2006.&nbsp; These notes require quarterly
  interest payments at an interest rate of 5.0% per annum.&nbsp; Interest expense
  related to these notes payable aggregated approximately $658,000 and $660,000
  in 2004 and 2003, respectively.&nbsp; At December 31, 2004, the current portion of
  these notes aggregated approximately $5,834,000 and accrued interest
  aggregated approximately $147,000 and $221,000 at December 31, 2004 and 2003,
  respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  In connection with the acquisition of Air
  Vent, the Company entered into an unsecured subordinated note payable to the
  former owner of Air Vent, in the amount of $42,295,000.&nbsp; The note is payable
  in annual principal installments of $8,459,000 on May 1, with the final
  principal payment due on May 1, 2008. The unpaid principal balance of
  $33,836,000 accrues interest at a rate of 5.0% per annum. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Company's private placement demand notes
  consist of a $25,000,000 senior secured note bearing interest at 7.35%
  annually, due on July 3, 2007 and a $25,000,000 senior subordinated note
  bearing interest at 8.98% annually, due on January 3, 2008.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  In addition, the Company has an Industrial
  Development Revenue Bond payable in installments through September 2018, with
  interest rates ranging from a fixed rate of 4.22% to a variable rate of 2.13%
  at December 31, 2004, which financed the cost of the expansion of its
  Coldwater, Michigan heat-treating facility under a capital lease agreement.&nbsp;
  The cost of the facility and equipment equals the amount of the bonds and
  includes accumulated amortization of $843,000.&nbsp; The agreement provides for the
  purchase of the facility and equipment at any time during the lease term at
  scheduled amounts or at the end of the lease for a nominal amount.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  In connection with the Company's purchase of a
  50% partnership interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC, the Company
  entered into a short-term note payable to Duferco Farrell Corporation in the
  amount of $5,000,000.&nbsp; The note bore no interest and was satisfied in 2004.&nbsp;
  </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0.5in">The aggregate maturities on long-term debt for
  the next five years and thereafter are as follows:&nbsp; 2005 - $14,692,000; 2006 -
  $14,493,000; 2007 - $191,295,000; 2008 - $33,559,000; 2009 - $100,000; and
  $55,900,000, thereafter.&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The various loan agreements, which do not
  require compensating balances, contain provisions that limit additional
  borrowings and require maintenance of minimum net worth and financial ratios.
  The Company is in compliance with the terms and provisions of all its
  financing agreements.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  Total cash paid for interest in the years
  ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 was $14,620,000,&nbsp; $12,632,000 and
  $10,050,000, respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT PLANS</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  Certain subsidiaries participate in the
  Company's 40l(k) Plan.&nbsp; In addition, certain subsidiaries have multi-employer
  non-contributory retirement plans providing for defined contributions to union
  retirement funds.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Company has an unfunded supplemental
  pension plan which provides defined pension benefits to certain salaried
  employees upon retirement.&nbsp; Benefits under the plan are based on the salaries
  of individual plan participants.&nbsp; The Company is accruing for these benefit
  payments based upon an independent actuarial calculation.&nbsp; The following table
  presents the changes in the plan's projected benefit obligation, fair value of
  plan assets and funded status for the years ended &nbsp;December 31:</p>

  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin-left: .5in">
  The plan's accumulated benefit obligation was
  $2,154,000, $1,791,000 and $1,652,000 at December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002,
  respectively. </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin-left: .5in">
  The measurement date used to determine pension
  benefit measures is December 31.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin-left: .5in">
  Components of net periodic pension cost for
  the years ended December 31 are as follows:</p>

  benefit cost charged to expense for the years ended December 31 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The medical
  inflation rate was assumed to be 8.0% in 2004, decreasing gradually to 5.0% in
  2011.&nbsp; The effect of a 1% increase or decrease in the annual medical inflation
  rate would increase or decrease the accumulated postretirement benefit
  obligation at December 31, 2004, by approximately $651,000 and $562,000,
  respectively and increase or decrease the annual service and interest costs by
  approximately $56,000 and $48,000, respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The measurement
  date used to determine postretirement benefit obligation measures is December
  31.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  The Company expects to make contributions of
  $144,000 to the plan in 2005.</p>

  follows:</p>

  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  On December 18, 2003 the Medicare Prescription
  Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the Medicare Act) was passed.
  On January 21, 2005 the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services released
  the final regulations for implementing the Medicare Act.&nbsp;
  Net periodic benefit costs for postretirement benefits above do not reflect
  any amount associated with the federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health
  care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is at least actuarially
  equivalent to the Medicare benefit because the Company was unable to conclude
  whether the benefits provided by the plan are actuarially equivalent to
  Medicare Part D under the Medicare Act. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">One of the
  Company's subsidiaries also provides postretirement healthcare benefits to its
  unionized employees through contributions to a multi-employer healthcare plan.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  10.&nbsp; INCOME TAXES</p>

  income taxes differs from the federal statutory rate of 35% due to the
  following:</p>

      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      $</td>
      <td width="65" valign="top" style="width: 48.6pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      61,927</td>
      <td width="55" valign="top" style="width: 41.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      $</td>
      <td width="65" valign="top" style="width: 48.6pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="text-align: right; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
      53,471</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Cash paid for
  income taxes, net of tax refunds, in the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003
  and 2002 was $17,584,000, $12,823,000 and $7,320,000, respectively.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  No provision has been made for U.S. federal
  taxes on a foreign subsidiary's undistributed earnings ($418,000 at December
  31, 2004) considered to be indefinitely invested.&nbsp; If these earnings were
  repatriated, the applicable income taxes would be substantially offset by
  available foreign tax credits.</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in">
  On October 22, 2004 the American Jobs Creation
  Act of 2004 (the &quot;2004 Jobs Act&quot;) was passed.&nbsp; The 2004 Jobs Act creates a
  temporary incentive for U.S.
  multinational corporations to repatriate accumulated income abroad by
  providing an 85% dividends received deduction for certain dividends from
  controlled foreign corporations.&nbsp; The Company has evaluated the repatriation
  provisions of the 2004 Jobs Act and has determined that no repatriations of
  unremitted earnings will be made. </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  11.&nbsp; &nbsp;COMMON STOCK</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In December 2003,
  the Company completed an offering of 4,500,000 shares of common stock at a
  price of $16.50 per share.&nbsp; Net proceeds to the Company aggregated
  approximately $70,000,000.&nbsp; In connection with this common stock offering, the
  Company granted the underwriters an option to purchase additional shares of
  common stock to cover over-allotments.&nbsp; In January 2004, the underwriters
  exercised this option and purchased an additional 321,938 shares of the
  Company's common stock at a price of $16.50 per share.&nbsp; Net proceeds to the
  Company associated with the purchase of these additional shares aggregated
  approximately $5,000,000, and was used to reduce outstanding debt.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: 0in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  12.&nbsp; STOCK SPLIT</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">On October 5,
  2004, the Company's Board of Directors authorized a 3 for 2 stock split in the
  form of a stock dividend that was distributed on October 29, 2004 to
  shareholders of record on October 15, 2004.&nbsp; The remittance of $1,000 in lieu
  of fractional shares has been reflected as a cash dividend and charged to
  retained earnings during fiscal 2004.&nbsp; All share and per share data in these
  consolidated financial statements and footnotes have been retroactively
  restated as if the stock split had occurred as of the earliest period
  presented.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  13.&nbsp; NET INCOME PER SHARE</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Basic income per
  share is based on the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.&nbsp;
  Diluted income per share is based on the weighted average number of common
  shares outstanding, as well as dilutive potential common shares which, in the
  Company's case, comprise shares issuable under the stock option and restricted
  stock plans described in Notes 14 and 15.&nbsp; The treasury stock method is used
  to calculate dilutive shares, which reduces the gross number of dilutive
  shares by the number of shares purchasable from the proceeds of the options
  assumed to be exercised.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The following
  table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share as of
  December 31:</p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  14.&nbsp; STOCK OPTION PLANS</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company has a
  non-qualified stock option plan, whereby the Company may grant non-qualified
  stock options to officers, employees, non-employee directors and advisers.&nbsp;
  Under the non-qualified stock option plan, 600,000 shares of common stock were
  reserved for the granting of options.&nbsp; Options are granted under this plan at
  an exercise price not less than the fair market value of the shares at the
  date of grant.&nbsp; These options vest ratably over a four-year period from the
  grant date and expire ten years after the date of grant.&nbsp; At December 31,
  2004, 228,750 shares remain available for issuance under the non-qualified
  stock option plan.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In 1993, the
  Company adopted an incentive stock option plan, whereby the Company may grant
  incentive stock options to officers and other key employees.&nbsp; Under this plan,
  2,437,500 shares of common stock were reserved for the granting of stock
  options at an exercise price not less than the fair market value of the shares
  at the date of grant. Options granted under this plan vest ratably over a
  four-year period from the grant date and expire ten years after the date of
  grant.&nbsp; In September 2003, this plan expired. The expiration of this plan did
  not modify, amend or otherwise affect the terms of any outstanding options on
  the date of the plan's expiration.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">In 2003, the
  Company's Board of Directors approved the adoption of a new incentive stock
  option plan, whereby the Company may grant incentive stock options to officers
  and other key employees. This plan was approved by the shareholders in 2004.&nbsp;
  Under this plan, 2,250,000 shares of common stock were reserved for the
  granting of stock options. These options are granted at an exercise price not
  less than the fair market value of the shares at the date of grant. Options
  granted under this plan vest ratably over a four-year period from the grant
  date and expire ten years after the date of grant. As of December 31, 2004,
  2,250,000 shares remain available for issuance under this plan.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The following
  table summaries the ranges of outstanding and exercisable options at December
  31, 2004:</p>

  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">At December 31,
  2004 all exercisable options had an exercise price below the $23.62 per share
  market price of the Company's common stock.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003 all
  exercisable options had an exercise price below the $16.78 per share market
  price of the Company's common stock.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">Tax benefits of
  $1,249,000, $949,000 and $349,000 realized in the years ended December 31,
  2004, 2003 and 2002, respectively, associated with the exercise of certain
  stock options have been credited to additional paid-in-capital.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: 0in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
  15.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;RESTRICTED STOCK PLAN</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company has a
  restricted stock plan and has reserved for issuance 375,000 common shares for
  the grant of restricted stock awards to employees and non-employee directors
  at a purchase price of $.01 per share.&nbsp; Shares of restricted stock issued
  under this plan vest on a straight-line basis over a period of 5 to 10 years.
  The Company recognized compensation expense associated with the lapse of
  restrictions in the amounts of $153,000, $212,000 and $258,000, during 2004,
  2003 and 2002, respectively.&nbsp; At December 31, 2004, 202,500 shares remain
  available for issuance under the restricted stock plan.&nbsp; </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  16.&nbsp; SEGMENT INFORMATION</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The Company is
  organized into three reportable segments on the basis of the production
  process and products and services provided by each segment, identified as
  follows:</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.5in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 1.5in">
  (i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  Processed metal products (formerly referred to as processed steel
  products) , which primarily includes the intermediate processing of wide, open
  tolerance flat-rolled sheet steel and other metals through the application of
  several different processes to produce high-quality, value-added coiled steel
  and other metal products to be further processed by customers.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.5in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 1.5in">
  (ii)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  Building products, which primarily includes the processing of sheet
  steel to produce a wide variety of building and construction products.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.5in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 1.5in">
  (iii)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  Thermal processing (formerly referred to as heat treating), which
  includes a wide range of metallurgical heat-treating processes in which
  customer-owned metal parts are exposed to precise temperatures, atmospheres
  and quenchants to improve their mechanical properties, durability and wear
  resistance.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">During the fourth
  quarter of 2004, the Company determined that SCM, which had been included in
  the Thermal Processing segment since its acquisition in June 2004, should be
  included in the Processed Metal Products segment, given the products and
  services of this business.</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left:0.5in">The following
  table illustrates certain measurements used by management to assess the
  performance of the segments described above as of and for the years ended
  December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002:</p>
